channel.title: What should I get?
channel.description: I managed to save up about $1,000 from working at McDonald's (ugghh) for the past 9 months and was planning on buying a new computer since the laptop I'm running has gone to shit. I haven't kept up with new technology as much as I should have, so I was wondering if anybody knew the best computer, most preferably a desktop PC, that I should/can get with the money I have.

item.title: What should I get?
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

Which country are you from, and are you okay to order parts from a website? I’ll build you up a nice cart once i get ur country. If you are in the US and your fine to order from newegg, your computer will be 30% better.

Read full topic

Why so many?[/quote]
stream multiple pornographic videos in parallel

item.title: What should I get?
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

1000$, hmm i think a pentium 3 will suit your needs, 256mb ram with a nvidia geforce mx400. should cost u around 100-200$ then spend the rest on 2 or 3 blue ray dvd drives.

Read full topic

item.title: What should I get?
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“davidude36, post:5, topic:226882”]$1,000 in 9 months? Man I feel for you, I make $1000 in two weeks.

need:
Processor
Motherboard
heatsink + fan (processor cooler)
a power supply box w/e they are called
Ram
a dvd drive
a hard drive
a case.
a keyboard and mouse
a monitor

you dont have to but these things you should look into:
a graphics card
speakers

When buying all these parts make sure they will be able to fit together and work together (e.g. buying a motherboard which will not fit into your computer case).[/quote]
processor fan usually comes with the cpu, at least with retail intel ones (not OEM)

theres little doubt he would want a non integrated video card if hes going to spend $1k on it

also, dont buy what you dont need when it comes to motherboards, a lot of them have useless features that you’re going to waste money on

Read full topic

item.title: What should I get?
item.dc:creator: @dragonfire455 dragonfire455
item.description:
@dragonfire455 wrote:

[quote=“davidude36, post:5, topic:226882”]$1,000 in 9 months? Man I feel for you, I make $1000 in two weeks.

need:
Processor
Motherboard
heatsink + fan (processor cooler)
a power supply box w/e they are called
Ram
a dvd drive
a hard drive
a case.
a keyboard and mouse
a monitor

you dont have to but these things you should look into:
a graphics card
speakers

When buying all these parts make sure they will be able to fit together and work together (e.g. buying a motherboard which will not fit into your computer case).[/quote]nice guide

Prebuilts suck, it’s better to build it yourself because people whom sell computers may not be trustworthy

Read full topic

item.title: What should I get?
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

$1,000 in 9 months? Man I feel for you, I make $1000 in two weeks.

need:
Processor
Motherboard
heatsink + fan (processor cooler)
a power supply box w/e they are called
Ram
a dvd drive
a hard drive
a case.
a keyboard and mouse
a monitor

you dont have to but these things you should look into:
a graphics card
speakers

When buying all these parts make sure they will be able to fit together and work together (e.g. buying a motherboard which will not fit into your computer case).

Read full topic

item.title: What should I get?
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

Don’t buy a pre-built with 1,000 bucks. Buy the parts and build one yourself or get another person to build one for you. I saved £250 ($500) getting mine built by a friend.

Read full topic
